title: The hidden tax bill a new partner could bring that could cost you thousands
text:

Critics have called for HMRC to overhaul the High Income Child Benefit Charge to protect the thousands of families who are falling victim to penalties every year.

The Office of Tax Simplification said an "urgent review" is needed into the charge which applies when the person claiming child benefit or their partner has an income of more than £50,000.

It means anyone with an income of more than £50,000 who moves in with a new partner who has children and is claiming child benefit, may trigger an unexpected tax bill even though they are not their children.

It also means households earning a joint £100,000 don't need to repay a penny - but households where one person earns £50,001, do.

"This little-known quirk is probably the last thing on anyone’s mind when they move in with a new partner," Sean McCann, financial planner at NFU Mutual, said.

"If you have a higher income than your partner and it exceeds £50,000, the onus is on you to tell HMRC and pay the tax bill. For some this runs into thousands of pounds.”

HMRC defines a 'partner' as someone you’re married to, in a civil partnership with or living with as if you were.

If one family has a sole earner on £60,000 and a non-working parent, they will be required to repay all of their child benefit. That is £2,500 a year for a family with three children.

Another family with two working parents earning £50,000, adding up to a household income of £100,000, would not be required to repay any child benefit and will receive the full £2,500 if they have three children.

Some people avoid the complexities of tax reporting by not claiming child benefit.

However, this can mean they lose out on national insurance credits towards the state pension, and their son or daughter will not automatically receive a national insurance number as they turn 16, which can mean they won’t pay the right amount of tax until they are able to arrange to get one.

These problems can be sidestepped, as guidance points out, by first making a child benefit claim, but then choosing not to receive payment of it.

Bill Dodwell said: "This is inherently confusing - and people can still lose out.

"The Office of Tax Simplification recommends that the Government reviews the administrative arrangements involved to improve the situation - and also looks at the position of those who have lost out since 2013."

Why you shouldn't just opt out - the important advantage of child benefit

(Image: iStockphoto)

Because 100% of child benefit has to be repaid when an individual has an income of £60,000 or more, many high earners have decided to simply opt out of receiving it. In 2017/18, 516,000 families opted out.

However, an advantage of child benefit that should not be ignored is that – until the child is 12 ­- it qualifies the stay-at-home parent for National Insurance credits which count towards the State Pension entitlement.

How to keep receiving child benefit while saving your family money

(Image: Getty Images)

One way to save your family money and the risk of this charge is to pay more into your pension pot.

For example, if the top earner in a family with three children earned £60,000, they could save £4,500 a year in tax by paying £8,000 into their pension.

The £2,000 tax relief on top of the £8,000 would take their taxable earnings down to £50,000. Not only would they save £2,500 from the child benefit charge, but they would also take their income below the 40% tax charge.

For a family with three children, this would result in an extra £10,000 in their pension pot at a cost of just £3,500, with a total of £4,500 saved in tax.

Another way to save is by opting out - and ticking the right box when you do so.

Anyone earning more than £60,000 can register to claim child benefit, but not actually take the money, so there's no need to fill in a self-assessment form to repay a penny back.

That's because when you receive the form for the benefit, you have two options.

You can either take the money and pay it back as extra income tax, or you can untick a box on the application form for a "zero rate" child benefit.

This means that you'll still be able to claim the credits without actually receiving the cash.

"Once a parent earns more than £50,000 they start to lose their child benefit, until it’s wiped out at the point when they earn £60,000 or more," explained Tom Selby, senior analyst at AJ Bell.

"This means those earning above this threshold often think they don’t need to bother claiming child benefit at all, but by not doing so they are missing out on crucial National Insurance contributions.

"As it’s often the mother who is off work with the child, it means they miss out on entitlement to the state pension, further exacerbating the gender pension gap.

"It’s good the OTS have identified that it’s ‘unreasonable’ the system works in this way and that individuals can unfairly miss out on vital state pension in later life because they haven’t claimed the benefit.

"The suggestion people should be able to claim back NI credits if they’ve missed out is common sense and the Government should reform the system to ensure that people understand the implications of not claiming child benefit."
description: Thousands of people are being hit by child benefit charges every year - but experts say it's time to reform the system
